text:
One of my clients offers credit cards specifically to startups. Of course, the ideal keyword to rank for is “best business credit cards for startups”, but the competition is very fierce with other websites such as Nerd Wallet, Forbes, WalletHacks and QuickSprout on the first page.

Our DA is 25 – is it worth writing a high quality article (I was going to do blog post, not a landing page) and trying to rank for this keyword? Or should I instead go for something like “benefits of company card”, which has much lower competition but is not as BOFU?

elements.text:
One of my clients offers credit cards specifically to startups. Of course, the ideal keyword to rank for is “best business credit cards for startups”, but the competition is very fierce with other websites such as Nerd Wallet, Forbes, WalletHacks and QuickSprout on the first page.

Our DA is 25 – is it worth writing a high quality article (I was going to do blog post, not a landing page) and trying to rank for this keyword? Or should I instead go for something like “benefits of company card”, which has much lower competition but is not as BOFU?

text:
IMO both. You’re going to want to rank for “best business credit cards for startups” at one point.

This pillar page is going to need strong internal and external links to prove its authority against the current players and this is something you can start as early as now. There’s also a concept which I haven’t verified myself so I’d love to get insights into this idea but the concept is that for difficult keywords, the updating process of the article is what is going to help slowly climb the ranking ladder. As in you will never compete with the first version of your article but if you update it/make it beefier every six months, this will help cement your authority on the topic/keyword and should translate in ranking increase over its life. It’s a long SEO game but it seems like this coupled with strong internal linking and external linkbuilding strategy is the way to rank for these big keywords.

As in you will never compete with the first version of your article but if you update it/make it beefier every six months, this will help cement your authority on the topic/keyword and should translate in ranking increase over its life. It’s a long SEO game but it seems like this coupled with strong internal linking and external linkbuilding strategy is the way to rank for these big keywords.

text:
Super helpful <@U013W748P7T> thank you! Yes, I did think I would have to do it anyway so might as well start now. Will be a fun experiment to see how long it takes to take it to the top of the page.

What do you think of this strategy: all the current competing posts are typical listicles with different credit cards. What if I did a blog post instead, explaining what determines a good startup credit card and why our product is good for startups specifically? (while also discussing other options as well as the pros and cons)

text: :pray:

<@U01MW6DPU72> One thing I've done is isolate different topics based on different stages.

Even pain points well before they look for a solution (but within the realm of what you do). So maybe in your case, it could be "Fastest ways to fund a startup" <-that's a guess.

Also: through a bit of research, if you discover x% of your customers are in a niche startup segment - you could target them also.

Also: through a bit of research, if you discover x% of your customers are in a niche startup segment - you could target them also.

text:
What are y'all doing for content process/workflow amongst larger, collaborative teams?

I'm defining things for a startup, not too dissimilar to how I’d documented processes at previous startups I've been with - outlined steps, checklists, and to-do’s - <http://auth0.com/blog/|auth0.com/blog/> and <http://netlify.com/blog/|netlify.com/blog/>, for example. Documentation developed here was within GitHub (where everyone was already working when publishing posts, pages).

But I'm curious to see what others may be doing/have done within Asana? Spreadsheets? Something else? How have you been documenting actionable content processes/workflows _that get used_? Thanks in advance!

text: <@U02C37FQVL5> this sounds really cool! It sounds like we do similar work. The content of your session sounds fascinating. I agree with the comments above that getting the "yes" for a full day might be tough. And, I wonder if you could pitch a similar session directly to the marketing people who work directly with their org's thought leaders (TLs). You could teach them how to get on the TL's calendar, what questions to ask, how to conduct the interview, etc.

elements.text: this sounds really cool! It sounds like we do similar work. The content of your session sounds fascinating. I agree with the comments above that getting the "yes" for a full day might be tough. And, I wonder if you could pitch a similar session directly to the marketing people who work directly with their org's thought leaders (TLs). You could teach them how to get on the TL's calendar, what questions to ask, how to conduct the interview, etc.

text: ...ctd because I stink at using Slack: In my work with TLs and their marketing teams, my goal is allllways to get 1:1 with the TL to have a juicy conversation with them. But I've found that the people who need to hear my framework on TL strategy are not the experts themselves, but the marketing teams around them. In many ways, marketers are my audience, even though I'm selling services for a TL.

elements.text: ...ctd because I stink at using Slack: In my work with TLs and their marketing teams, my goal is allllways to get 1:1 with the TL to have a juicy conversation with them. But I've found that the people who need to hear my framework on TL strategy are not the experts themselves, but the marketing teams around them. In many ways, marketers are my audience, even though I'm selling services for a TL.

text: Last thing: I have been experimenting lately with new ways to get into TLs' heads. If they can't spout off genius insights on demand on a Tuesday morning call (when they're on a packed day of calls), I've been testing new ways to get to know them and to help them develop their ideas. I've started using Voxer (1:1 audio messages) with a couple of super senior people and they can do it in the margins of their day, when they're walking the dog, etc. It's so casual and 1:1 and unfiltered by PR/marketing people that they really like it and I get such good off-the-cuff thoughts from a channel like that.

text:
Competition for this term is too hard. You do not have the resources nerd wallet has either.
Its not like the competition is going to just chill either.

Find a less competive term higher or lower in the funnel.
You make have to cover the content anyway for topicaly and also for sales enablement.
I like your idea of different angle. If you not going to rank meet the intent but create a new angle

text: Live and die by <http://Monday.com|Monday.com> and their automations and forms! Each marketing sub-team (ie content, ppc, design, video ...) has their own monday board that lists out all open tasks. and each board has a form which anyone in the company fill in - filling in a form creates a task on the team's monday board.  for example, i (content team lead) receive a form request, and i assign it to a writer. then the writer will move it along through each stage of approval, legal, etc, and eventually pass it to the design board (all fully visible to the person who opened the task). it's mostly all automated and very straightforward :slightly_smiling_face: we've been using monday for years but only recently synced the boards between teams and it's been a huge help in keeping everything on track.

we've been using monday for years but only recently synced the boards between teams and it's been a huge help in keeping everything on track.

text: I’m looking to create kind of a destination resource for all-things related to one topic…in this case it’s onboarding. Iv’e got a guide or two, a webinar, a bunch of blogs, i want to be known as kind of “the place to go” for all things onboarding. Does anyone have any examples of these types of pages? Doesn’t have to be about onboarding but just something that is a great resource page for content. Guess i’m kind of looking for more layout/design examples than anything

text: Usually you'll see these referred to as Content Hubs or Topic Clusters. We have a bunch of examples of various approaches here: <https://www.contentharmony.com/blog/content-hubs/>

attachments.title: Types of Content Hubs: 5 Approaches & 30+ Examples
attachments.text: Getting your site architecture right is one of the harder parts of building a site, whether you’re dealing with millions of pages or hundreds. These patterns will help you understand the best way to create yours.
attachments.fallback: Content Harmony: Types of Content Hubs: 5 Approaches & 30+ Examples
